title: Centor Score (Modified/McIsaac) for Strep Pharyngitis
description: Estimates likelihood that pharyngitis is streptococcal and suggests management course. Modified version includes age adjustment and provides evidence-based approach to antibiotic prescribing and testing decisions.

parameters.name: tonsillar_exudate
parameters.description: Presence of tonsillar swelling or exudate

parameters.name: tender_cervical_nodes
parameters.description: Swollen, tender anterior cervical lymph nodes

parameters.name: age_years
parameters.description: Patient age in years (affects scoring: 3-14 years +1, 15-44 years 0, ≥45 years -1)

result.name: centor_assessment
result.description: Centor Score with probability of streptococcal infection and management recommendations

ranges.interpretation: Score ≤1: Probability of GAS 1-10%. No testing or antibiotics recommended. Symptomatic treatment only. Consider viral etiology.
Score 2-3: Probability of GAS 11-35%. Rapid antigen detection test (RADT) and/or throat culture recommended. Antibiotics only if positive test results.
Score ≥4: Probability of GAS 51-53%. Strong consideration for empiric antibiotic treatment or testing with RADT/culture. High likelihood of bacterial infection requiring treatment.

references: Centor RM, Witherspoon JM, Dalton HP, Brody CE, Link K. The diagnosis of strep throat in adults in the emergency room. Med Decis Making. 1981;1(3):239-46. doi: 10.1177/0272989X8100100304.
McIsaac WJ, White D, Tannenbaum D, Low DE. A clinical score to reduce unnecessary antibiotic use in patients with sore throat. CMAJ. 1998 Jan 13;158(1):75-83.

McIsaac WJ, Kellner JD, Aufricht P, Vanjaka A, Low DE. Empirical validation of guidelines for the management of pharyngitis in children and adults. JAMA. 2004 Apr 7;291(13):1587-95. doi: 10.1001/jama.291.13.1587.

Shulman ST, Bisno AL, Clegg HW, Gerber MA, Kaplan EL, Lee G, Martin JM, Van Beneden C. Clinical practice guideline for the diagnosis and management of group A streptococcal pharyngitis: 2012 update by the Infectious Diseases Society of America. Clin Infect Dis. 2012 Nov 15;55(10):e86-102. doi: 10.1093/cid/cis629.
formula: Modified Centor Score = Tonsillar exudate (1) + Tender cervical nodes (1) + History of fever (1) + Absence of cough (1) + Age adjustment: 3-14 years (+1), 15-44 years (0), ≥45 years (-1). Total range: -1 to +5 points.
notes: Modified by McIsaac et al. 1998 to include age adjustment
Age 3-14 years: +1 point (higher risk of streptococcal infection)
Age ≥45 years: -1 point (lower risk of streptococcal infection)
Score ≤1: No testing or antibiotics needed (1-10% GAS probability)
Score 2-3: RADT and/or culture recommended (11-35% GAS probability)
Score ≥4: Consider empiric treatment or testing (51-53% GAS probability)
Current IDSA guidelines recommend testing before antibiotic treatment
Should not be used as sole decision-making tool - clinical judgment important
Valid for both children and adults presenting with sore throat
Does not apply to patients with recent streptococcal exposure
Consider alternative diagnoses if recurrent episodes
